item.title: Needed a lightweight stove
item.description:
On Friday, I needed to get a lightweight stove for a quick camping microadventure on Saturday night. I did not want to buy one and was considering self heating meals and no coffee in the morning. Until I found inspiration from a post on twitter to a video by Tom Allen.

I decided to have a go at building my own also. I had some mentholated spirit for fuel, I just needed a drink can to make the stove. After a quick trip to the local shop, and with my thirst quenched I had my raw material.

Trimmed the top and bottom sections. Bottom section is about 30mm high, the top is about 50mm.

Creat flues in the side of the can with a knife. Small at the top. Large at the bottom. These form the generator.

Mate both sections

The ridges are critical. They are small at the top, large at the bottom. They form the fuel generator.

Add a small hole using a pin just under the top lip.

Add a small amount of fuel, approx 5mm deep.

Light, wait 10 seconds for fuel to heat in the generator.

Once hot the fuel vaporises in the side ridges, which is the generator the flames only burn on the outside.

It took about 5 minutes to boil two cups of water.

Weights very little too.

Field test!

I was pleasantly surprised by the stove, it had no trouble heating my dinner or boiling water in my coffee maker. Just keep it out of the wind.

If you want to know how these work. Check out this page.

item.title: Southdowns Cycle Rides
item.description:
A couple of years ago I managed to get round to getting myself a new Mountain bike, a Boardman if you are interested she is on the right there and rather filty, they are great value. Since then I have been trying to do as many of the tracks on my local Ordnance Survey map as I can.

I have not got round to putting down all of the info on the rides I have been doing locally, but you can see them on Everytrail. I have spent the winter trying to do every track I can on the Ordnance Survey 1:25000 map for Brighton.

Also you'll find the GPS tracks for the Afan Forest rides we did. Awesome rides, you should go if you get the chance. Make sure you and your bike are fit!

I hope someone finds the tracks useful / interesting!

item.title: Ford Railway Station to Devils Dyke Walk
item.description:
Wendy and I, have recently walked from Ford railway station to Devils Dyke, we followed the Arun river up-stream past Arundel to Amberley, were we spent the night. From there we walked along the South Downs Way to Devils Dyke. We spent the night in Amberley which is a fantastic little village in Sussex. We recorded the journey with Everytrail, you can follow the link here if you are interested in the Everytrail recording. We plan to do some more walks in the future.

For our overnight stay we managed to get a booking at Stream Cottage which is in the heart of Amberley and run by a wonderful couple. The breakfast is superb! Unfortunately I was unable to eat it all... For dinner there are a few pubs in Amberley, I had the Mixed grill at the Black Horse
